Sep 16 2009 	Writing from the hotel room now...	As I type this in the hotel room, I would like to explain that I am not accustomed to such luxury. To me it is luxury, to others is it not.---I am staying at this hotel for about 2 weeks. For the past 3 years I have been coming to Beijing, to see family. Although smoggy with disastrous traffic, I love this city.I entered the hotel with my cousin via taxi. There are two doormen whose job is to push the rotating door for you.That was strange...but awesome.The street level floor has reception and the bar. On either side of the floor is Chanel and Louis Vuitton. On the two bottom floors there are more designer stores like Armani. The reception staff was very nice and they spoke English very well. Of course if you cannot understand English with a Chinese accent, you are doomed.Their accents were not too bad, but I am used to it.If there is something mundane that a hotel traveler is used to and their is a staff person close, they will usually do it for you.Example, a receptionist pushed the up button for my cousin and I, when we were going towards the elevator. The bellhops bring your bags to the door. Mine were 2 heavy duffel bags, so they brought two people.The hotel is located 1 block or so from Wangfujing street, a popular tourist spot that has everything you might need. Immediately around the corner there is a market where you can buy water, snacks and shampoo. I recommend not drinking the tap water if you have a sensitive stomach or if you are not from China. It can easily upset your stomach. Boiling the water is fine though.---Still trying to recover from jetlag, I caved and ordered the Chinese breakfast room service.Also, I do not know what "business casual" actually is for the restaurants...haha.For 24 USD, it is quite a helping of food.Congee (rice soup), fresh fruit, fresh juice, chinese pickles, tea, dimsum and noodles.They even had little mini char siu bao!It was very good, although not as good as homecooked.I decided to head to the pool before my spa treatment.You sign in with your room number. If needed you can have a locker key to keep your things in. I was not sure how to dress when going down to the pool, so I just wore my clothes.Inside the locker they give you a towel, a bathrobe, poolside slippers and a few coat hangers.Before you enter the pool, you must walk through ankle deep water to clean your feet.A woman is inside the pool area to assist you. When you enter she lays out towels on a sun-chair, gives you a bottle of water and a magazine. There are also goggles if you need them.She spoke enough English to communicate the needs.The pool was a little cold, I will admit. Then again it IS 84 degrees outside....Although I do not know if it her job, I assume it is, she turns on the shower for you and dries your bathing siut too. I am used to using the bathing suit dryers myself, so I assumed the patron did it. But she said no no and dried the other half of my suit.--- If you stayed with me through this whole review, congrats!But joking aside, I really do like this place.If you are a business person or are used to total luxury hotels, this might not be for you.I am the kind of person who does not need an extra sitting room.

Aug 27 2009 	Recommended but doesn't quite live up to the Peninsula Standard	We stayed at the Peninsula Bejing for 6 nights in a Grand Delux Room. We had two reasons for choosing this hotel:1. The location2. We stayed at the Peninsula in Bangkok and were hoping this would be a similar experience.Firstly the location is excellent. Aug 13 2009 	One of the Best in Beijing	We have stayed in the peninsula for 3 nights in June 2008. The hotel is very well located for the main shopping and also for dinner. Aug 10 2009 	The place to stay in Beijing	I stayed in the peninsula for three nights in July. Jul 30 2009 	Everything top of the line...	Conveniently located within an easy walk to the Forbidden City, Tienanmen Square, the pedestrian shopping street, and "food alley", the Peninsula never lets your forget that you've signed up for five-star service. Friendly, competent hotel staff listen to your requests and answer all your questions. The rooms weren't overly large, but they were well appointed with TVs in all the bathrooms, and free wireless internet in the room. The buffet breakfast is wonderfully diverse, complete with everything from fresh-squeezed OJ, bagels with lox & cream cheese, and con gee. I would definitely stay there again.

Jul 24 2009 	I've Seen the Promised Land	I've never had a more pleasant hotel stay than my recent week at the Peninsula Beijing. Everything was first rate. In fact, the service was so over-the-top attentive that, for an independent-minded sort like myself, it was mildly annoying, at times--like the bathroom attendant who turns on the faucet for you. But I mean that in a good way, if that makes any sense. Pay up to stay on the club floor. The included breakfast alone is worth it--good coffee, a broad selection of Eastern and Western foods--and the happy hour (also included) is a very pleasant bonus after a day spent working or touring a sometimes hot, clamorous city. Plus--for you non-Mandarin speakers--the staff in the club speaks the best English in a hotel where nearly everyone speaks well. The Peninsula's gym and the pool are some of the better ones I've seen in a hotel. They were included in the price of our room as was internet access. And the location, assuming you want to be in the center of the city, is excellent--an easy walk from all the major sites.

Jul 21 2009 	Best in town!	I have stayed at the Peninsula Beijing several times, and it is ALWAYS good!From the moment they pick you up at the airport with their swanky Rolls Royce it sets the standard for the perfect stay. Ok, the lobby is a little 90s with the tacky marble horses and staircase, but it is the people that works here that makes the stay memorable! The rooms are very comfortable with all the equipment you can desire. The towels are the thickest you can get anywhere. The spa is a part of the ESPA chain, that you can experience on other top hotels as well. Great treatments everytime, but expensive.....Pool and fitness area are top notch!You have to try the crispy duck in the restaurant in the basement, worlds best! The interior of the restaurant is also worth an extra glance, spotless and cool! In a city where service still is "a new kid in town", the Peninsula is the place to be!

Jul 10 2009 	Top notch service	I have absolutely zero complaints about this hotel. The room was great and we had plenty of room. Bathroom with TV was excellent. The bed was hard, but still comfortable if that makes sense. Every member of the staff was extremely helpful. It's really the small details that impressed me - when I had to call housekeeping, the woman answered the phone in English and used my name (almost all the employees called me by name). After calling housekeeping to get some drinking water one time, I didn't have to call anymore. They would come into our room when we were gone and leave us tons of water and fresh ice. The location was good, however we encountered a few cabs throughout the city who refused to drive us to this hotel. I don't know if they didn't know where it was or just didn't want to go there. Breakfast was great - omlettes made to order, waffles, fruit, pastries, breakfast meats, and some Chinese selections as well. Service at breakfast was outstanding. You don't expect your chair pulled out for you at a buffet, and certainly not everytime you get up. Breakfast was inclulded in our room rate. I wouldn't have paid for it otherwise as it was expensive to purchase on its own.Overall, this was an excellent hotel and not as expensive as other Peninsulas.

Jul 6 2009 	Old classic but luxurious and dependable as ever	I stayed here for 4 nights in June and got an excellent rate via the British Airways website. I first stayed at the Peninsula Palace Hotel about 9 years ago and have been back many times. Despite the huge growth in number of international 5-star hotels in Beijing, this grand hotel is still one of the very best. I cannot understand why this hotel is not ranked in the top 3 in Beijing. The service here is as impeccable as ever. Staff in the restaurant at breakfast are attentive and efficient. The buffet breakfast is excellent with many choices. The rooms are very comfortable, although without an expansive view (as most rooms will look into a neighbouring office building). The Chinese restaurant in the hotel is one of the best in the city. The location of the Peninsula cannot be beaten, a few minutes from the department stores on Wangfujiang and a few minutes away by taxi from the Forbidden City. There is a supermarket around the corner for snacks and bottled drinks if you do not want to use the more expensive minibar in the room. Across the road are 2 other newer hotels i.e. the Regent and the Legendale. Both of these hotels look good although I cannot make a comparison as I have not stayed at either. The Peninsula is an excellent choice and a safe bet for those who want a comfortable hotel with proven great service in an excellent location. There is a high end mall (e.g. Chanel, Gucci etc) in the basement levels of the hotel although this is usually empty of shoppers. Note - as the hotel is located in an area of 5-star hotels, and therefore abound with "wealthy travellers" by Chinese standards, you are likely to be approached by young women offering "massage services" if you go walking in the evening. Pretty harmless but worth being aware of. I would definitely recommend this hotel and will come back here again, despite the competition.

Jun 21 2009 	Luxurious and perfect for a biz trip but lacking personality	This is definitely a 5 star hotel with very nice rooms and top notch service. If I were going back for work, I would definitely stay again. However, if you are going to Beijing for fun, this might be a little boring. It feels very luxe, complete with high-end shopping mall built right in. I supposed I was hoping for a bit more old school Peninsula.

Jun 16 2009 	All nice and fancy but it lacked something	Excellent service; great breakfast; AMAZING spa - out of this world. But the rooms were smallish and there was something lacking with the place. Think more memorable places exist for less money.

Jun 9 2009 	Tops as usual	The staff is great; rooms are fine; service is excellent. The shops in the hotel "ain't" bad either.The location is convenient for sightseeing. We just like the hotel!!

We ordered for some Yang Zhou fried rice at midnight (an hour after the Cantonese restraunt had closed), but the friendly man on the other end of the phone got hold of someone from the overnight dining kitchen who made a variant of the fried rice (he admitted it wouldn't be "original") which was very good!!overall very well appointed hotel, great spa, good pool (though heated, but temp. should be kept higher than it is) and very prompt service (housekeeping as well as in room dining)

May 4 2009 	Excellent value for money would stay there every time	This was our first Peninsula and we had been warned that it wouldn't match up to the lofty standards of its sister hotels in New York and Hong Kong. We don't have that for comparison but we did compare it against our stay in the Four Seasons in Shanghai and the Peninsula beat it marginally despite it being a lot older. The staff was genuinely friendly and we appreciated the guest officer taking us on a mini tour of the room. We loved the amenities provided as well as the bathrobes and bed. There was a wide variety at breakfast, sufficient to satisfy any craving, and we really felt welcomed everywhere we went. We had afternoon tea at the Peninsula (provided as part of our Winter Escapade package), which was good, although not quite as glamorous as its Hong Kong counterpart. One good thing about the hotel is that it provides complimentary high speed internet access in its rooms - high time other hotels followed its example and stopped charging an arm and a leg for internet service. We wouldn't hesitate recommending this property to anyone.

Apr 20 2009 	Great time while there but then there was afterward...	Booked a winter special package for an overnight stay in mid-December. I had to fly in and out of Beijing for just one night for a business-related event, and loved the service. For CNY 1300, I had a standard room, plus free breakfast, and a round-trip (not one-way, but round-trip) airport transfer in one of their new BMW 7-Series. The had a large sign with the person in a hotel uniform waiting for me at the airport, who took my bags and called down for the car to pull around. After a short ride, upon pulling into the hotel there was a full staff of people standing outside (in the December cold) for my arrival. One to open the car door, one for my bags, one to open the hotel door, and one who was taking me straight to my room to check-in(no front desk). Once in my room, I relaxed, went down to the pool while having my clothes/shoes prepped for the evening, and enjoyed taking a swim. The pool attendant laid out towels for me, brought bottled water, but would walk along side of the pool with me as I was swimming laps, a little strange having a stranger watch me swim back and forth. Came back and with my evening attire ready and laid out in the room, went off for the evening to my event. The next day, woke up and went to breakfast (also included) and was wowed by the selection and quality of the offerings, I was thoroughly pleased and stuffed. Same car service upon departure to the airport. Those who know Beijing (I used to live there, now in Shanghai) know that a taxi from Wangfujing area to the airport can be about 100 yuan, so with RT limo service saved 200 Yuan i would have otherwise been forced to spend. (Found out afterward that their standard fee for limo service is usually CNY800 one-way) Plus free breakfast, free internet, free pressing and shoe shine, I felt like it was a steal for what I paid, and the service was nice the whole time. Two complaints though (one small, the other big), first is that the room was on the small side, I really felt it could have been a bit bigger, but it was tastefully decorated and relatively modern (with 42-inch plasma). When walking into the room it was kind-of like a "this is it?" reaction. Second was their billing. I gave them my credit card for the room guarantee, but paid cash. Usually a guarantee (at least in my experience) is used for minibar charges when you leave or if something is un-settled and you are gone. The evening after I had left, I found out they had charged my credit card for the room (plus extra), even though my bill was paid in full, in cash, upon departure, and I had to wait 2 weeks for them to take the charge off. Was un-happy when I learned this, especially since my credit card was charged more than what my actual bill was (by almost US$100). Was embarrassing when I went to use this card and told that I didn't have enough balance (and I couldn't think of anything at all i actually purchased with it), and upon logging into my account see a charge on my card for Peninsula Beijing, when I'm holding the bill that says paid in full, in cash. Kind-of ruined my great feeling I had when I left the hotel. The hotel itself was a very nice experience, but I still don't understand their billing office.

Mar 30 2009 	Lovely Stay	We spent 3 days at this hotel. The rooms were quite large. the Tv in the bathroom was a nice touch. Free internet was very convenient. Location was good. I just read another review, which seems to be the opposite of what we felt...this proves the great VALUE of tripadvisor. WE found the rooms to be very clean, and the service spectacular.The mood lighting in the room was very pleasant. The hotel is a bit stuffy with all the high end shops there, but its was still a very relaxing feel. The bar in the Lobby was great, snacks given to you with your drink... nice touch. The front desk and the concierges, all assisted greatly in providing directions, making reservations, and just translating a bit of chinese for me.The Spa on the other hand is WAY over rated! it is beatuiful, nice facility, but for the price i am sure you could find one for the same price and double the time. I didnt like trying to be sold one of their products.. especially after a relaxing time. If i want to buy something , I'll ask...but dont try and sell me. In the end, its your typical hotel massage.The breakfast buffet is truly huge and amazing. Pretty much everything you would want is here, and if not they'll make it. we worth the price, even though it may seem steep. We skipped lunch for 3 days cos we were full from breakfast... eliminating a lunch bill. Essentially you wont save anything... but you wont end up spending more either.We arranged a cab...not thru the hotel, but on our own, with the translation help from the doorman, for a trip to the Mutianyu section of the wall. the first quote was 900RMB, we coutered with 600, and the price was accepted. So for this price, we went to the wall, olympic venues, and the hou hai area.Also the next day we used the same cabbie for and all day rate of 500 rmb...to be our driver for 9hrs. this was perfect.ok... back to the hotel. Prior to the trip, their email correspondence the very prompt.

Mar 23 2009 	Ok Hotel but terribly poor service and poorly managed	I've stayed at this hotel this past winter on a business trip. Traditionally, I've stayed at the Grand Hyatt, China New World, and the brand new Regent hotel (during the Olympics). This is about my 3rd time staying here but the first time in at least 6-7 years. First off, Pros: Good location and access to Wangfujing shopping. It's about a 10 minute walk to Wangfujing and 25-30 minute walk to Tiananmen square. Location can be important and this is a good locations. Rooms were good, main room is nice and acceptable for standards. Dining facilities are good. Cons: Outdated bathrooms. Terribly expensive and not a good value. My bigger issue is with the poor, slow service. Staff are slow, do not understand the need for prompt service. For example, we requested house-cleaning THREE times to come to our room because we had dry-cleaning that had to get done for our conference. Finally after the third call and approximately 45 minutes, they finally came around. My other massive gripe is the poor management of the hotel. First off, the hotel is in no way flexible with hotel changes. We were charged a "no-show" fee since we arrived one day after their system had said we were supposed to arrive. Either this was our corporate travel's error or Peninsula's error but when we asked Peninsula's front desk to address this issue, we received a "This is company policy" response. No flexibility, no hospitality. Nothing. It's not a very welcoming feeling that we got and I have to say the staff throughout the hotel was not very welcoming and we couldn't see them this way for the rest of our trip. Upon two occassions at two different breakfasts, we observed two different caucasian department heads (I think one chef and one other manager) berating Chinese staff for their performance. While this may be fine in private settings, these two managers did so in a publicly EMBARASSING and DISGRACEFUL manner that should never be accepted. The public disparaging remarks of these two managers were both unacceptable and made some of us patrons and guests uncomfortable. Upon the second manager pulling this action, we approached the manager and politely informed him that their actions were creating an unpleasant atmosphere for us. The manager responded, "Thank you for your input. If there is anything other input we need from you, we'll let you know.." It was both aloof and terse and quite insulting. For the standard that the Peninsula is supposed to exhibit, it falls very short. If any of you see the caucasian chef or hotel managers berating the staff in public, hope you all can speak your mind to them as well.

Feb 27 2009 	LOVED this hotel!	My son and I stayed at The Peninsula Hotel, Beijing, in December 2008. We spent more time in our rooms than we had intended because the weather was so bitterly cold. Feb 9 2009 	Impeccible Service	In the last 3 years, I have stayed at this property 4 times, and will return again soon. I also stay at the Shangri-La in Beijing, but I find this location much better. Jan 28 2009 	Good stay at the Peninsula but .. ??	This trip to Beijing was purely for business, and based on recommendations and previous experience with the Peninsula in Bangkok I opted for the Peninsula. I must say, it is a good hotel (on the border to a great one too at times). Service is on the mark.. however, there was something 'missing'. Nov 10 2008 	It's Definitely Growing On Me	I stayed at this hotel twice in the last two months. The first time it was just an overnight trip, and perhaps I only noticed some of the drawbacks of the hotel - chiefly the room sizes, which were designed in a different age when rooms (in the early 1990s) were not expected to be huge in deluxe hotels like many are today. There isn't a walk in shower, for instance, and just has the old standard - the walk in shower, albeit with the hard sliding screen. The hotel is definitely old school and of a certain age - with Chanel and Gucci stores in the lobby. I guess the first time I came, I expected to be absolutely blown away by a different class of hotel that people might expect of the Peninsula. That wasn't the case, so I was a little disappointed.However, I stuck with it for my recent visit in early November, and this time, having more realistic expectations of a regular 5 star hotel, I was actually impressed. I guess it's not quite like the Peninsula Hong Kong or Tokyo, but few hotels are. This hotel also has a totally different room tariff structure, so it's not like many of the negative recent reviews paid US$300 a night.The room is actually attractively designed, and is very comfortable. The bed was wonderful, and I disagree with a previous reviewer that the breakfast buffet was wanting. If you like Chinese breakfasts, you are in for a major treat. The congee and the condiments were delicious and there were so many choices I felt I'd need to eat there 3 nights to try everything.I looooved the gym. The machines were state-of-the-art, the decor was beautiful, an attendant would bring you a cold towel in the middle of your workout and all the water you'd want, and best of all there was an iPod jack in the machines so you could plug in without running your battery down.And not enough can be said of the location. Some people might like the Grand Hyatt location better (as it is closer to Tiananmen) but I feel the Peninsula is closer to the attractions and shopping on Wangfujing and surrounding streets and it's easy to hop in a cab and go anywhere. My walk from the Great Hall of the People to the hotel one night took just 20 minutes (at a brisk pace).The hotel is not going to bowl you over. But I thought all the service staff had an excellent attitude and were very helpful. You particularly may not find a more competent concierge staff than at the Pen in Beijing.

Nov 4 2008 	Below par service and staff for a Peninsula....	We just spent 5 nights at the Peninsula Beijing because I got a great rate on the room with breakfast and wanted a safe and comfortable place since it was our first time in Beijing. It is in a solid location, close to everything. Unfortunately our first 24 hours there were a bit unsettling. We checked into in a deluxe room (fancy name for standard), which was comfortable. First the toilet had problems but that was quickly fixed. That should have been a warning of the things to come. We had a good evening and a yummy breakfast at the buffet. At the buffet, there was a wait every morning we went down regardless of the time. There was only one person seating the guests and the line often backed up. How could this be for a buffet breakfast?! Obviously they need to review their staffing charts. Once seated, there were lots of servers but unclear on what the did either. I actually filled out the comment card since there did not seem to be enough servers inside refilling coffee/tea either. To be honest, we had better service at Sheraton Saigon than the Peninsula Beijing. The Sheraton buffet put theirs to shame. I'm a huge Starwood fan and had debated between the St. Regis which was a tad farther from the center but now wonder wish I had stuck with my loyalties. I figured in Asia, Peninsula is the gold standard after our stay in the HK Peninsula. Sadly I was wrong. If that is their benchmark, they have a long way to go!After breakfast on day 1, we returned to our room, which we had cleaned. Looking to change into jeans, I quickly realized they were no where to be found! Luckily I had worn them on the plane and into the hotel, so I knew they had to be somewhere, but definitely were no longer in our room. I was NOT a happy camper. My husband and I went down to reception. He was paranoid about his computer, since it did not fit into the tiny safe they provide. This was the first time, we had a safe the size of a shoe box. Upon informing the hotel resident manager, the housekeeper came to our room. The head of housekeeping also showed up but was very unsympathetic (surprise, surprise,....). We spent over an hour talking in circles of translations to track down my jeans. Miracliously, after insisting they be found, the housekeeper had an epiphany and recovered them...........in another guest room. I was highly confused and not comfortable with the hotel at all. We even went to the watch the security video but the mystery of how my jeans went from the desk chair in our room into another guest room remained a mystery. At the end of the day, all I wanted was my jeans back and am glad we were so aggressive with the staff. Sad that we had to be, since we had missed the first full morning of first day in Beijing. After the general manager arrived, he apologized profusely and promised us to move us to another floor. No, I did not want the same woman cleaning our room going forward. Upon returning from our outing, they moved us into a suite with a larger safe. On day four of our stay, we learned that this room actually had access to the club floor. It would have been nice to know this benefit sooner. The club floor was highly unimpressive, especially since they had four staffers standing in the center to greet you but then continued to converse among each other while you tried to figure out what was available. It made you feel like you were invading their club, versus them being at your service. Highly bizarre. Funny how when another colleague arrived at the floor and went around to help guests, they just continued to socialize. Highly unprofessional.I would NEVER pay full price for this hotel. I had read earlier reviews about this hotel not being that modern. The facilities and rooms are fine. I have issues with the staff and service, which is what typically differentiates the Peninsula vs. its competitors. So sad....In Beijing, I would highly recommend you stay with an American chain, where they understand how to manage guests and not take guests' possessions. Yes, I am still mystified by the disappearance of my jeans.

Nov 1 2008 	Should rename to Pennysula hotel	It is supposed to be one of the best hotel in Beijing, but we were very disappointed. We reserved a king size bed, instead we were given 2 double beds when we checked in. It took almost 30 minutes to check us in. No tissue paper, no tooth brush, was supplied in the room, running out of toilet paper was a norm, by the way, the toilet paper was so hard and poor quality, I went out to get my own. Any yet, they still only provide you with 2 half roll each time. Go figure!The staff were polite but the service at the cafe was below average. The breakfast was expensive and the food was always the same. Breakfast was RMB 250+ a person, fresh squeeze orange juice, good egg omelete should be a must for that price. The juice was diluted with water, and the omelete was oily with a tiny spoon of ham and mushrooms, you can't even taste the cheese even though I had order double cheese. After 2 days, we went across street to Novotel and had our breakfast there. It's not only cheaper but more selections. The Novotel breakfast buffet was RMB 149+ per person, I don't mind the juice not freshly squeezed for that price. The chef there made me an omlete exactly to my order, little oil with lots of ham, mushrooms and cheese. We had our lunch in the Chinese Restaurant at the Penisula, I could not believe the tiny portion. Compare to the Grand Hyatt Beijing around the corner, this is an expensive hotel in price only.

Oct 30 2008	Far over priced for its old facilities and poor service	The Peninsula Beijing is old and tired. The rooms are small and the furniture is old. Bath and shower are in one unit. The bath is dirty and dark and leaks all the time. Tiles are cracked and toilet is marked. Lift lobbys carpet is badly stained and smelly. Breakfast spread is poor and the service is bad. Cold tea and coffee is served in cold days and you have to fight to keep your cutleries as they dont replace them. Bar waitresses have close-to- zero knowledge on alcohol. The gym is poorly facilitated and staff has no English ability. Best surprise of all, if you are Asian looking, you may get rude treatment from their European manager as well!In Oct 2008,I forgo the chance of staying with our 5-star corporate hotel for The Peninsula Beijing, formerly known as the Palace Hotel for its name and my good memory of it fifteen years ago. I paid the market rate of over USD$330 for 3 nights. On the day of arrival, airport pickup staff held a piece of soft A4 paper with very vague print of hotel logos on, lazily standing far away from the arrival gate. Limo is good provided you can survive the 10 minutes walk with smoke and crazy traffic through the whole car park.. The Reception opened up a wrong room initially and I had to wait for 30 minutest for the correct room booked. Once in, I was shocked to see the five-star hotel with a sound reputation worldwide having very small and old fashioned guest rooms. Different from many other young 5-star hotels with rain shower separated from bath, the Peninsula's traditional handheld shower is built inside the bath which looks dirty and old and difficult to climb in. Shower water leaks and runs all over the bathroom floor even when the screen is shut. There are cracks on the wall and dirty dark marks inside the toilet bowl. Room Service setting up the welcome fruit plate looked angry when there were no tips given.Out of the 3 days stay I had to queue for breakfast 2 mornings! The Jing restaurant has poor spread of food and the staff speaks very little English. Cold tea and coffee were served all the time and my cutleries were always taken away without being replaced. There was no presence of restaurant manager for the 3 meals I had there. Lobby bar girls did not understand what a Bailey on Ice was and told me there was no such drink. When a supervisor finally brought the drink, it came without ice. Gym facilities are also poor and backwards. There are treadmills with 80% channels playing mute, dumb bells and 1 assistant who does not speak English. One more interesting incident - I walked to the staff's area by mistake and got lost. An European hotel manager interrogated me by asking for my identity and room number and escorted me out very rudely!The Peninsula Hotel Beijing is in general old and tired. Although the expatriate management staff is still hired to manage the hotel, the traditional English management presents to be way out of fashion now. Most of all, its charge is far too high for its old facility and poor service.

Oct 12 2008 	Amazing Breakfast!	Location of this hotel was only 5 min walk from the main shopping area and around 15 mins to the Forbidden City, around 20 mins to Tiananmen Square. The hotel overall is excellent but for the price, the room was a bit small with a very small bathroom. Also be careful of the sippery floor in the bathroom - quite dangerous. Price of the hotel may have been higher than usual due to the Paralympics being held in Beijing.Breakfast was the best thing about staying here! It was amazing. A wide variety of western and Asian dishes, cooked in front of you and made to order.Generally a very good western style hotel.

Aug 27 2008 	Very nice but.........	Our usual hotel in Beijing was full so our travel agents put us into The Peninsula. As you would expect from such an establishment the staff/service and rooms were impeccable and the whole place exudes an atmosphere of luxury living. The hotel is also very conveniently located for shopping/sightseeing.The downsides though are the so-called Lobby Bar and the Jing restaurant. It's difficult to understand why so many hotels in this city think you would wish to relax with a drink whilst you watch fellow guests check in and luggage trolleys shuttle to and fro. I really don't wish to sit in reception whilst I sip a gin and tonic so surely a dedicated and separate bar would be a good idea. There's plenty of room for one if some alterations were made to the deserted (and very expensive) shopping arcade at lower ground floor level.The hotel's website records a testimonial from Conde Naste Traveller magazine suggesting that the Jing restaurant is "one of the world's top 75 new restaurants". The people from Conde Naste really should get out a bit more because if their statement is true then I'm a banana! I had both dinner and breakfast in Jing (the latter because I couldn't believe breakfast could be that bad - it was). Both were bland and (by Beijing standards) expensive with little to no inspiration which is surely the principal idea of a "fusion" restaurant.Do give the hotel a go but I'd book a restaurant outside.

Aug 26 2008 	loved the Peninsular	After taking a long and exciting tour around China, taking in all the usual sites, We returned to Beijing to saty at the Peninsular to celebrate our wedding anniversary. We were not disapointed , our room was lovely ( club room ). The club lounge was excellent from the check in to departure. Infact it was so good we had to tear ourselves away to venture out side. Would recomend this hotel the service was excellent.

Aug 17 2008 	Loved this Hotel	A wonderful week, close to fantastic shopping street, we arrived the day before the Olympic torch arrived. People couldn't have been nicer, Jing was fab for food and meeting other Americans.Our stay included visits to the Forbidden City, the Great Wall, and Summer Place and a lunch at one of the wonderous restaurants where the waiters and waitress dress as the Emperor and Empress did, plus the food was great. Our next stop Xian.

Aug 17 2008 	Olympic Gold	Stayed for 5 nights in the run-up to the Olympics and before the corporate sponsors took over all the major properties for the Games.Your other reviewers have commented on the age of the hotel car fleet. Well, they are now all brand new BMW 7 Series augmented by a couple of long wheel base Rolls Royce Phantoms all in British Racing Green, making for a pleasant airport transfer.We stayed in one of the Beijing suites on one of the higher floors. Suite was very large, well furnished and equipped. Excellent standard of housekeeping and overall a good place to relax and recover from the oppressive heat and draining humidity. Suites give access to the Club Lounge which was well served with friendly and polite staff.Spa is now run by Espa and was good with strong Chinese traditional massage. Pool is a respectable 18 metres and benefits from daylight. Clean and well tended.The Huang Ting Chinese restaurant was excellent with friendly service and delicious dim sum for lunch and an addictive Peking Duck which was the best we have ever eaten. Enjoyed the Lobby Bar which was buzzy and with a first class jazz trio for late evenings. The lychee martinis were delicious.Yes, it is populated by every luxury brand outlet including Harry Winston, so it is perhaps a bit of a high-end mall but it clearly cements its status as the Grande Dame of the high end hotels in Beijing.Location is the real winner, it is walking distance to Tiananmen and the Forbidden City and doormen were very helpful in providing directions for taxi drivers to less well known sites such as Beijing's interesting mosques.In a city with plenty of competition for your custom, the Peninsula delivers in terms of service, continuous investment and attention to detail. Not all others will last the marathon.

Jul 19 2008 	Great Stay	Some friends and I stayed at the Peninsula Beijing for 3 nights in May 2008. It was the first stop of a three week trip throughout Asia and the Peninsula Beijing set a pretty high standard for the rest of our accommodations to live up to. Although the bathrooms aren't as luxurious as those found at other Peninsula properties, this hotel had many outstanding amenities.Check -in was quite fast and efficient. The check-in person was incredibly helpful. He was kind enough to exchange some dollars while we dropped off our bags and hailed us a cab so we could hit the nightlife before it got too late.The hotel lobby is nice and the lower levels have quite the shopping selection (all high-end boutiques: Louis Vitton, Cartier, et al). The lobby bar seemed a bit out of place but was nevertheless fun. The car we were taken in was quite old, worn and out dated.Other than that, the Peninsula Beijing is in a great location and provides wonderful amenities. Jul 18 2008 	Amazing my fav hotel so far!	The Peninsula is just amazing, the room is huge and beautiful, the bathroom is beatifully done. The luxury shops at base level/ground level also makes the penisula stand out from other luxury hotels in Beijing. Enjoy live piano/classical music while taking a tea break and also the hotel restaurant Jing is highly recommended! The autosphere is beautiful and the food is the best I've had in a chinese restaurant. The breakfast is also great, with a wide range of western and chinese food. Some people might say the peninsula beijing is not on the same standard as the peninsular in Hong Kong or else where, but at the same time, remember it is also a lot cheaper. Jul 11 2008 	Sub-Standard for a Peninsula Hotel	At first glance upon entering the Lobby the evening I checked in, I thought this would be equivalent to both Hong Kong and the Beverly Hills properties in terms of service/quality and overall impression. I was wrong. Service quality is just not up to standard of their other properties. No one seemed willing to go out of their way to help or assist. The thing I love about the other Peninsula properties i have stayed at is that they almost anticipate my needs before I even ask. This was not the case at this property. The standard rooms are also very small. Free bottled water comes once a day in the evening around 8pm - and they are small half bottles so you ould wait all day to have something to drink in your room again. One one day, i had the privacy button turned on in my room and when i came back tomy room, the maid was actually in my room cleaning it! They need better training. I had left some valuables out in the room and was not happy about this. Their wi-fi service was slow and intermittent, althought complimentary. The hotel was virtually empty (as were many other Beijing hotels at this time) and yet the hotel was unwilling to give me an upgrade (for a fee) to the club floor. The hotel airport transfers were sub par as well -- the greeters at the airport were disorganized and made us walk around the parking garage with them to find the car instead of keeping us in a pick up spot to wait for the car to come to us. When it did arrive, it was an OLD model mercedes which compared to other hotels like the Mandarin Oriental or Regent, was very below standard. I would not use their car service again for the amount of money paid (about $100 each way). Doormen were pretty god for getting taxis. Restaurant Jing was a good breakfast buffet but on the expensive side - $40 a person. Overall, i would not recommend this property, especially for those of you who regularly stay at Peninsula Hotels. I will stay at other luxury properties on my subsequent trips to Beijing. There are several newer properties like the Grand Hyatt, and the Grand Millenium, as well as the Regent.

Jun 12 2008 	a nice hotel but some drawbacks	We spent four nights at the Peninsula Beijing with two rooms for the four of us on a club floor. The rooms were attractive and comfortable, nice bathrooms, nice bath products. There is a nice lounge chair next to the window for sitting, as well as a desk with good access to outlets etc. When you enter the hotel, there is no lobby as such, the lobby consists of a large staircase, a bar/lounge, and Chanel, Hermes etc etc store. It is really a tacky retail environment, I don't care how "exclusive" those stores are, I expect an actual lobby with a place to sit and wait for people without having to buy a drink. It feels like a mall.There is NO place to sit in the lobby.The club offered excellent breakfast, snacks, hors d'oeurves at dinner hour, and drinks. The staff in the club were friendly, helpful, and really welcoming. Only complaint about club room was that the only comfy upholstered chairs and sofa were in the smoking area, and at one point they acrtually let someone smoke a cigar. The entire floor smelled, as there is no real separation beytween smoking and nonsmoking.. The location is an easy walk to Wangfujing St with the night market, etc.This is a nice plush hotel but given the lack of decent public areas, I think it is not really special.
