Don't walk, its too far. We negotiated a driver from the hotel and were slightly overcharged. We let the conierge desk know for their information and it was no big deal. Within minutes the unrequested difference in cash in an envelope was slipped under our door. Can you imagine that happening in any U.S. or Canadian Hotel ? Asia is all about service and China specifically about "saving face". The people here are very welcoming.The Club floor is excellent. When you arrive, don't be put off by the outside appearance. It's what's inside that works and works nicely. The hotel run "Jing" restaurant is beautiful, but overpriced and like most places in Beijing, it's okay to smoke while others dine. Oh, and "Made In China" is a very good restaurant in the Hyatt hotel, a short walk from the Peninsula. Reservations are a must,and make sure you tell them you want to order the Peking Duck or Beggars Chicken, after all, you are in the land of origin.Get the hotel to organize a car and driver along with an English speaking guide to go to The Great Wall. We spent 9 hours with these guys and it cost about $180.00 U.S. One note, it includes lunch. Lunch is a stop at a government run gift store. You wont eat the food, unless you have been on a fast for 37 days. Tell them to pass on the lunch-stop and figure out food for you, your driver and guide on your own. Some nice touches with the "turn-down" services in your room at night.

Nov 8 2006 	Palace indeed	The Peninsula Palace is a great, great hotel. The lobby bar is one of those fantastic melting pots of a meeting place with young, hip, rich Beijingers loaded down with shopping bags from the hotel's high end designer shops rubbing shoulders with foreign journos, other expats and Chinese business people. It has that real international hotel feel.The rooms, as everyone has said here, are supremely comfortable and the staff accommodating, friendly and highly professional. I did find the bed a bit hard but got used to it.The pool and massage facilities are great. Brenda's foot massage rocks!The breakfast at Jing is only surpassed by the brilliant buffet dinner there. Great value and amazing food, running the gamut from east to west in delicious style.After a day's sightseeing and shopping in mad, frenetic, exciting, wonderful Beijing, the Peninsua Palace is a truly relaxing haven and home away from home that will have you refreshed and ready to go again the next day.We were there for four nights during the Sino-African summit with the president of Egypt and Guinea and their entourages in-house. The way the hotel handled the extra security and associated busy-ness bodes well for the 2008 Olympics.

Nov 3 2006	Treated like a queen	Arrived at hotel late in the day,and very tired from long flight.Rooms were ready and luggage in room before I was.Bed was turned down with a mint on pillow. Two bottles of water furnished every day by hotel,saved us from having to purchase.Buffet breakfast a good mix of western and Asian food.GOOD COFFEE! When you passed hotel emplyee's ,always a smiling hello,Doors opened for you whenever you went out and again when you returned.Mattresses were the best in all the trip.For a change my back wasn't killing me when I got up.Wished I knew brand,would buy one for my bed at home.Thanks to all the staff at the Palace for making the start of my China vacation so great.

Oct 31 2006 	Extremely pleased	I reserved two Grand Deluxe rooms for a week at The Peninsula Palace Beijing during August 2006. I was extremely pleased. The exterior and the lobby are austere and clean. The check-in was easy. The room was sharp, clean and nicely appointed. Even the corridors were spotless, as if the hotel had just opened. I was a bit concerned about the room because photos on TripAdvisor, and on other sites, make it look rather spartan. As soon as I settled in, though, I realized that the reason the room looks so unassuming is because there was a place for everything and everything was in its place. The room design is well thought out. It was always a pleasure to come back to after a day of sightseeing in Beijing. The breakfast buffet in the Jing restaurant was outstanding with many choices. The entire restaurant was sparkling clean. The open kitchen was immaculate. It was a pleasure to wake up to that delicious breakfast every morning. I ate once in the Huang Ting restaurant and found it too was delicious. The staff was attentive, courteous and professional. Most spoke English and those that did not were eager to do there best to help. The morning that I checked out, I had forgotten my password to the room safe and someone was in my room to help me open it in less than 5 minutes. I can only think of two things to complain about. First, I found the bed to be a bit on the hard side. Second, the room rates are pricey. That having been said, however, it is not enough to make me not go back to the Peninsula. In fact, I did just that in late October 2006. I showed up there without a reservation and they were able to accommodate me immediately. It felt like going home again even though it was only for a night this time.

Oct 31 2006 	Great Stay	We just spent three nights at the Peninsula, and were very pleased.We stayed in an executive club room for a very reasonable price.The 5 star rating is deserved. The hotel car picked us up and when we pulled up at the hotel a concierge met us at the curb and took us directly to our room and checked us in there. We had fresh fruit and chocolates waiting for us. The room was spacious and attractive, with a large plasma screen in the wall of the bedroom/sitting room plus another small one in the wall of the bathroom. You could sit in the bathtub and work wall control buttons for the TV, radio or speaker phone. Like most hotels, the makeup lighting in the bathroom was poor. I called the valet looking for three common room amenties I couldn't find - because they were more tastefully out of sight than I expected.Club room amenties were good, however you have to arrange tours at the concierge desk in the lobby to book tours and guides. Every concierge who waited on us did an excellent job and all the private guides they got for us were excellent. We would definitely book this hotel if we return to Beijing.

Oct 5 2006 	Pampered at the Peninsula	Spent four nights at the Peninsula Palace in September. The Bedroom on one of the executive club floors was terrific - huge bed, internet conections, air con that obeyed us, flat screen TV and even a second TV in the bathroom! The Executive Club rooms could not be faulted with speedy check-in and check-out , great breakfasts and a splendid happy hour. The hotel is in an ideal situation near to Beijing's main sights and a shopping area. Restaurants were fine

Oct 3 2006 	It's not cheap but very nice	I stayed on the club level for 2 nights while on business. The service was flawless and the location excellent. I think some may expect a more luxurious stay for the amount of money, but to me the courteous and attentive staff more than compensate.

Sep 12 2006 	Overrated	The hotel is over rated. I had planned on staying at the Peninsula for seven days; the first two days in a standard room re-checking in 4 days later in a club level room. The hotel lobby is what you would expect from a "5" star hotel, however, the room was the size of your standard room with a small unimpressive bathroom and the room was getting close to needing to be refurbished. It definetly was not the room I was expecting. I am sure I could have stayed at a hotel with a comparable room for 1/3 the cost.The room rate did include a wonderful breakfast and a dinner at the Jing restaurant which was excellent.The hotel is well located being close to the main shopping area and many of the important sights in Beijing. On the way to the Forbidden City we walked by the Raffles Hotel which had just re-opened and stayed there for the balance of our trip and had an outstanding stay for less money than the Peninsula.

Sep 4 2006	Outstanding	Recently spent three nights in Beijing at the Peninsula. From the pick-up at the Airport to the check-in in our room by the Club level with Tea and Fruits and Snacks, the hotel service was outstanding. Walking distance to Forbidden City, Shopping, Tianmen Square. Booked tours through the hotel and they were perfect, we booked group tours but noone else signed up so we had private tours of the Great Wall, Forbidden city etc.. The hotels Club level lounge had wonderful breakfast and evening appetizers and drinks. Rooms are outstanding with no short-comings.

Sep 2 2006 	Great experience; highly recommended	I stayed at the Peninsula Beijing from Aug. 25-29, 2006. I was on a business trip, but my parents joined me in China for a week-long vacation and we stayed at this hotel in two separate rooms.I was very pleased with the hotel. The service was excellent, the location is very central, and the room was exceptionally nice. (My photos don't really do it justice.) The fitness center is pretty good, and the pool is nice and was not crowded when I visited. Housekeeping is exceptional -- several times between visits to the room I noticed that they had spot cleaned and refreshed towels, made the bed, etc. The hotel is very well-staffed, and every person I met spoke basic English. The front desk staff speaks excellent English, and I noticed that many of the managers are European.I didn't think that the outside of the hotel is terribly attractive, but the inside more than makes up for it. (That said, my mom loved the outside.)I've stayed in the Grand Hyatt (twice) and a Novotel in Beijing, and overall I prefer the Peninsula and would definitely stay there again. The Grand Hyatt is very nice (and also nearby) and it has a better fitness center, but the Hyatt is usually more expensive and I think the service at the Peninsula is more friendly and less chain-like.Room service for dinner was excellent. I only had the breakfast buffet at the hotel, which was okay but not great.FYI, after a recent renovation the hotel is now just "The Peninsula Beijing" -- it's not called The Peninsula Palace anymore but it's the same hotel.

Sep 1 2006 	Disappointing Peninsula	We booked a non-smoking, deluxe king room on the club floor at supposedly the best hotel in Beijing. It was very disappointing. First off, they gave us a smoking room - there way of making it non-smoking was removing the ashtrays when we pointed out to the bellman that it appeared to be a smoking room. Second the room was quite small. Crowded for two people. The bathroom was really substandard. It was a tub shower and it leaked everywhere. We planned to check out after the first night and move to the Grand Hyatt. However the Club Floor manager found out about our plans and they offered us a bi-level suite (at an increased rate) which was nicer, but still not up to the level of a 5 star hotel. I stay in a lot of 5 star hotels and this just isn't up to par. The lobby and restaurants and excellent at this hotel. Definitely worth a trip to Jing or Huang Ting for dinner, but stay elsewhere.

Aug 24 2006 	I liked it!	I stayed at this hotel at the beginning of August booking directly at hotel website where I found a very valuable package including a round trip transfer from Airport.The hotel is very elegant but not to much opulent (which I don't like). In the lobby you may find an arcade with the most well known fashion brands, but , I don't know why, they are the 20% more expensive than Italy.The room is very nice and clean; you can undestand tha the hotel is very new. Big flat TV and very interesting control board for lighting and more from the bed table. Bathroom is not that big, but there is also a flat TV (never seen something like that).The location is ideal; clean and safe area walking distance to the shopping area and very close as well to the forbidden city and the markets.I would stay here without any doubt in the future.

Aug 13 2006	A Palace it is and Staff at their best	My husband, 9 year old son and I stayed at the Peninsula Palace Hotel August 3 - 6, 2006. During that time they had a summer promotion on and you had to be crazy not to book it. For a five star hotel they deserve every one of those stars. The summer promotion included breakfast (buffet) everyday and it was quite the buffet - western and asian as well the option of dining in their 5 star restaurant JING that is known throughout the city or you could choose transfers to/from the airport your choice.The check in and bags to the room had to be in record time. Once inside the room they have unbelievable features, like when you enter the room you have the option of mood lights (when was the last time you went into a hotel room that had mood lights) doesn't work with a 9 year old. The plasma TV was amazing and you can order from a list of DVD's that are delivered to your room and there is no charge for this service. They have a sitting area as well as a desk with a fax machine and internet access to use of course if you are on business. The bathroom is quite large nice counter area, separate shower area, nice deep bathtub - phone right by the toilet and a tv screen in the bathroom really what more do you need. We weren't even on the club floor.My husband and I had a chance to use the fitness facilities if you work out this is the hotel to book. We have travelled a lot all over the world and this is the BEST hotel gym you could ask for it is big and has very good equipment. A lady also runs around with a basket after you and offers water and asks if you need anything - beats our local gym! For swimming which our 9 year old did the pool is more than enough fun - clean and big and very well maintained - it is indoors but they also have lounge chairs in case you want to sun yourself outside.. The conceirge is more than staffed - they speak many different languages and of course being the height of summer season especially for Asia they look after everyone - no job is too big or small for them. Including recommending shopping places for all the women that have empty suitcases. Dinner reservations are not a problem and if you want to go to the Beijing Opera you can book that as well. Local tours are offered with shuttle or bus pick up as well very specialized tours that need 24-48 hours notice - if we had had more time in Beijing we would definately booked the educational ones. I can't say enough about the conceirge they really look after you and I really couldn't tell at one point how many staff they had - one day there were six behind the desk looking after everyone what they don't want are lineups and believe me you don't have to wait. The hotel is surrounded by expensive shops on three floors ie Channel, Coach, Tiffany you get the idea - I saw people with bags but never actually saw anyone shopping in the stores - I know they must do well. So if you are humming or hawing where to stay i would highly recommend this hotel - you are in a stones throw of Wangfujing Street which is one of the MAIN shopping areas - like department stores, Olympic Souveniers an awesome Arts and Crafts Centre many floors high with all kinds of Crafts including the Jewellery section on the main floor. You can also walk to Tiananmen Square takes about 15 minutes but a cab is quick and cheap as well. The Peninsula used to be called the Palace Hotel and if you are reading an old guide to Beijing you might not see the hotel in your book - The Peninsula Chain bought it and of course changed the name what a great buy. It's more than a Palace!

Aug 7 2006 	Excellent with a few grumbles!	Excellent with the following comments:- agree with previous reviewer re. price of Evian bottle. Had same experience but refused and sent it away.- booked a car and guide to the great wall. The guide just rides with you for the trip and stayed behind the walk on the wall. I don't understand the point of it and why we had to pay for a useless service.- both inhouse restaurants very good.

Aug 7 2006 	Best hotel in Beijing	I've stayed at almost every 5 star hotel in Beijing but found Peninsula as the best in town (price/location/value). Travelled dozens of time to Beijing from 2004 through June 2006. Rooms are comfortable (love that TV in the bathroom), location is fantastic (don;t need to take a cab to go to restaurant /shopping/ foot massage). Personnel is very attentive, concierge desk is very efficient and helpful.

Jul 23 2006	Great Hotel - So-So Service	Stayed for seven days. Liked the room. Service on the Club level was fantastic. The entire staff was friendly and helpful during our morning breakfast and afternoon cocktails. They serve a very good "free" breakfast and evening buffet. The staff made us feel like honored guests day after day. I cannot say the same for the front desk and conciege. They acted as if we were a big bother. We actually were afraid to talk to the conciege after being talked down to and given one or two word answers to our questions. We were very lucky to find a local guide to give us recommendations - the conciege at this hotel was worthless. Front desk and money change desk were hard pressed to even say hello. Seemed like they just wanted to get you in and out. No smiles. Management needs to spend a day at the Peninsula Manila or Peninsula Chicago to understand what customer service is all about.

Jul 18 2006	Good Hotel - Do not trust the Cocierge Recommendations	A great hotel - rooms, restauarants (especially Jing), ambience, and perfectly located to explore Beijing.Just one warning - do not trust the advice and recommendations of the Concierges. We booked an expensive city tour. The guide was excellent but she had been asked not to tell us beforehand that many of the sites were undergoing renovation and would be closed (improvements for the 2008 Olympics). We also asked for advice to get to one of the large Carrefour supermarkets and were directed to a very poor, older, smaller supermarket than the one requested. Restaurant recommendations? Not very experienced and it was as if they received a commission on recommending certain establishments.The Jing Restaurant was always very good .... especially the buffet.Beware of ordering certain items in the restaurants and cafes - a bottle of Evian cost GBP 8 so order the local mineral water. The tea and beer were very reasonable.A great hotel to stay in but .....

Jul 16 2006	NIce location and excelent conciege service	We stay in the hotel for 5 nights. The room was big enough to accommodate the 3 of us.As I made reservations by e-mail before, they wait for us at the airport with cool water and a Mercedes. They bring us to the hotel, and we went directly to the room (no check-in was necessary).A week before I communicate with the concierge by e-mail asking for suggestions, and asking for travel arrangements. When we arrived they have already book everything we want (private tours, shows, and restaurants). Everything works fine, and we are very happy with this and all other services of the hotel.On the top of all, the hotel is very well located, the breakfast is excellent, and has a very kind staff.For those that have never being in China before, and do not want to be part of an excursion it is a very good and safety option. I will do it again if it is necessary.

Jul 8 2006	Executive Floor makes it best in China	We booked three rooms on the Executive level and received the best in service. One of the rooms did not have potable water, but we could call for as much bottled water as desired. The Club Lounge had an excellent breakfast buffet, superb afternoon tea snacks, and superb bar snacks and foods with drinks at happy hour. Our family loved the fitness center with the individual tvs, headphones, bottled water, and provided cool moist washcloths midway through the workout. Superb hotel laundry service. The location was superb for proximity to a pedestrian shopping street and a night market. Also close to a night food market.

Jun 25 2006	Nothing Outstanding	Stayed at the Peninsula Palace for three nights towards the end of May. The room was standard size with a king-sized bed. The bed was a bit hard - especially given that most luxury hotels these days provide very comfortable beds. There is a big plasma tv in the room and another small one in the bathroom. I did not have the same problem as the other reviewer with regards to yellow water and leaking shower stall. Location of the hotel is very good - as it is close to many of the sights and a major shopping mall. What surprised me was the level of service at the hotel. I flew to Beijing from Shanghai where I stayed at the JW Marriott and I noticed the big difference in the level and consistency of service. At the Peninsula, they have excellent and knowledgable staff at the concierge, but the front desk staff was not too pleasant -- same with some of the page boys and door men, who are a bit aloof. There was even an occassion wherein the housekeeping staff left their wipe cloth in the room. Otherwise, service at the business centre and at the Jing restaurant was excellent.

Jun 23 2006	It's better when you get inside!	The Peninsula Palace looks terrible from the outside, and the trip from the airport (by taxi) will leave you wishing that you'd never come to Beijing, but once inside it's a different matter.We arrived - nerves frazzled after the 100mph dash from the airport - in a far from relaxed state and as soon as we stepped out of the cab our bags were whisked away, we were taken up to the executive lounge and offered a beer. Good start!The concierge in the executive lounge couldn't have been more helpful, providing us with maps and information, and taking us personally to our room.Unfortunately, despite reserving a non-smoking room, the first room we were given smelt badly of smoke. No problem! We were given a choice of two other rooms and our bags were moved without any fuss or trouble.The rooms aren't overly opulent or fancy, and the views aren't good, but they're very clean, modern and comfortable.Location wise, the hotel is perfect for tourists. It literally is a 15 minute walk from the eastern edge of the Forbidden City (to the person who said in a previous post, "don't believe the "15-20 minute" distance from the Forbidden Palace/Tiananmen Square you hear" - I think you must have got lost - you go out of the hotel, turn left and walk in a straight line for 15 minutes!!!). It's 2 mins from the main shopping street (which is good to look at but not great for shopping) and right across the road from the most amazing foot massage place we've ever experienced (amazing after a day trekking round the city).We were going to go on a trip to the Great Wall arranged by a youth hostel but it was too much hassle, so we asked the concierge to organise a car to take us to Jinshanling and pick us up at Simatai. They also provided us with a great lunch. This was not cheap, but it was worth the money for the experience.Overall - a good hotel in a good location and perfect if you're only in Beijing for a short time to "see the sights".

May 25 2006	Good Hotel	In the past I have only stayed at the Peninsual's in Bangkok (possibly the world's best hotel) and the Hong Kong Pen (an institution) so we were expecting an equally grand hotel. We arrived late and their car met us at the airport. All very standard stuff for most of Asia. Arriving at the hotel we had booed into the club floor.They take you directly to your room. A disappointment, to say the least. Tiny rooms and even smaller bathrooms in comparison with their other Asia hotels. So we had them locate another room, and negotited a small extra amount to pay. Much better. At least we could unpack and move around without too much problem. And a bigger bathroom too. The club floor had a pretty good breakfast. They will go out of their way and make you eggs to your choosing if you ask them nicely. The staff were all very helpful. They put on a snack and cakes in the afternoon. Chocolates after dinner, so it's not a bad place to retire to before bed. Free internet service as well. The restaurant is excellent and the breakfast there is huge. One day we hired a car and driver to take us to the Great Wall. The restaurant maitre d' ( a delightful ladt with an excellent command of english) assisted us in haveing a picnic lunch packed., We chose food from the cold food buffet the night before in containers she provided and kept them in the kitchen fridge. The next morning they packed it in a small ice chest and provided us with linen and plates and cutlery so we could enjoy the meal. At the Great Wall our driver took us to a gift shop at the bottom and waited with the food while we spent a few hours on the Wall. We then ate at one of their tables. This was much nicer than the restaurants we passed on the way.The hotel is located close tt Tiamen Square and the Forbidden City (about 25 minutes walk) and next to a huge car free mall. We enjoyed the hotel. Excellent staff. Super Chinese restaurant in it too.

May 24 2006	Very good hotel but spotty service	My partner and I stayed at the Beijing Peninsula Palace hotel in mid-January and would recommend it to others who seek acceptable luxury in Beijing.ROOMOur room was a deluxe room, but take note that not all deluxe room are created equal. Our first room was much smaller and did not have a TV in the bathroom. We complained and were given a larger room in the same category on a higher floor. This room had a separate "office" area tucked into a corner of the room. It had a silent fax machine, broadband access and the usual Peninsula technologies. The bed itself was not to hard, and it was prepared for us nightly. I'm not sure however that they changed the sheets every day. BATHROOMThe bathroom didn't have a separate shower cubicle. Our bath's sliding glass door leaked quite a lot of water and the water pressure while adequate, wasn't that strong. Oh, and do remember to let the water run from all the faucets for five minutes. China being a Third World country, doesn't have good piping so the water is yellow. They do have a separate faucet which dispenses potable (clear) water.FACILITIESThe hotel itself was quite luxurious on the exterior. We used the pool area, the sauna and the gym - All were top class. We dined at Huang Hing restaurant (very good) and had daily buffet breakfast at Jing (also very good in quality and choice). SERVICEMy only main gripe is that the service of the hotel was spotty! We arrived late in the evening and while the staff were attentive, their tone was rude at times. The front desk lady actually said, "OK, that's it! You can go!" when she gave us our key - I was hoping that the management could have trained their staff to avoid the famous Chinese "no-nonsense" (i.e. rude by Western standards) mannerisms and word choice. The service in Jing was also spotty - We asked for Jasmine tea every day and it was either late in arriving, or was forgotten altogether. In terms of cleanliness, we noticed a lot of fingerprints on the mirrors and table tops throughout the hotel. Again, this is a minor issue but unacceptable in this type of hotel category.SURROUNDINGSFinally, as for the surroundings of the hotel, don't believe the "15-20 minute" distance from the Forbidden Palace/Tiananmen Square you hear. My partner and I are avid walkers and it took us a good 35 minutes to get to those mentioned locations. The hotel itself is in a nice shopping area however, and the CONCLUSIONOverall, this is a very good hotel. Perhaps, as an expat residing in ultra-high service and ultra-polite Japan, I'm more aware of the small service details. As such, don't expect the exact same type of service you're used to from back home. I'm sure that in time, the level of service will improve once China develops further.

May 15 2006	Beautiful Hotel! Too bad our new Levi's were stolen from it!	We were pleasantly surprised that we were staying in the nicest and most beautiful Hotel in Beijing. Clean, wonderful breakfast buffet, good service, robe and slippers provided. The only thing negative we went home with, was the realization that levi jeans must be very valuable because my husbands were taken from the room. He left them folded on the entertainment stand and they were gone when we returned. Otherwise, we loved the Hotel.

May 8 2006	Very nice place to stay	I stayed at this hotel for 4 nights. The staff was very pleasant and always eager to accomodate. The hotel was very well maintained. The food was excellent. It was nicer than most places I have stayed in New York- and the people were a whole lot friendlier. I would definitely go back

May 6 2006	A bit of an enigma	In many ways this hotel is superb: the facilities are terrific e.g. a very fine gym and nice indoor pool. Rooms have excellent plasma TVs and fine showers. The "club floor" lounge is very welcoming, doing breakfast but also afternoon tea and complementary drinks in the early evening. Service was excellent throughout in my experience, helpful and freindly. Oddly, the breakfast was patchy, with eggs cooked to order, but cold baked beans, tea that was also sometimes cold, and some very ordinary dim sum indeed. At peak times, there was a long line for breakfast; we waited 20 minutes one day to get into the dining room (which is one level below the lobby). However the main problem was the beds, which had rock-hard matresses. According to my physician wife, it is a myth that hard beds are good for your back, and these were the hardest I can recall in all my travels. Overall, very good, but if you have any trouble with hard beds, look elsewhere.

May 2 2006	Heaven in Beijing	The moment we arrived we were wisked away to our upgraded duplex suite. It was a stunning room with magnificent lighting. We were greeted with beautiful fresh fruit and a display of cookies and chocolate. The service was perfect. The concierge arranged every detail of our 5 night stay from front row opera tickets to a window table at the Courtyard restaurant.We took the hotel transfer service to the airport which included a personal escort to our ticket counter. Since we were not traveling with a tour the personal service we received during our entire stay made our trip to Beijing memorable. I wouldn't hesitate staying at the elegant Peninsula again... I would look forward to it.

May 2 2006	very good	Stayed for 4 nights in March, great limo service which picks up from the airport if you pre book it 60 each way. The hotel is very chic, the foyer is amazing, surrounded by many designer shops, Louis Vuitton, Chanel, Dior, Prada, Tiffanys and many more. The prices of the restaurants were steep by Beijing standards. But if you don't mind the prices then the quality of the restaurants is very good, particularly the Cantonese restaurant.The hotel is very well located, a 5 minute walk to the shops but a good 15 mins to the Square and Forbidden City. I suggest getting cabs as they are very very cheap, get the concierge desk to sort them out for you, they are very helpful.We got the hotel to organise a trip to the Great Wall and Qing Tomb for us with a Red Star car. It was very good, get a packed lunch from the hotel to take with you. The standard room was very nice, plasma screen, all fittings new and shiny. Wasn't the biggest room I have ever stayed in but more than big enough. The bed was one of the best I have ever slept in and the sheets were lovely and soft.I would recommend the hotel to anyone going to Beijing, not the cheapest but certainly very good quality, chic, reliable and central. Beijing itself is worth a visit, especially the Great Wall, an experience i will never forget. The Silk Market is the place to go for bargain shopping, once you get used the hassle from each stall holder you realise that its just their sales pitch and isn't meant to feel as intimidating as it does at first. Some fantastic bargains to be had, my girlfriend said she would go back to Beijing just for that market!

Apr 23 2006 	Ok But Will Go Elsewhere When Next in Beijing	I had heard raving reviews of the Peninsula Hotel Beijing, but I was disappointed. For US $300, I did not think this belongs in the 5 Star category. There is nothing special about the lobby, although the hotel is located in a mall with all the shopping of brand names on Rodeo Drive or 5th Avenue. The location was what bothered me. My wife and I walked several blocks in all directions, but there was nothing interesting to see, even along the nearby pedestrian street. The dining room is in the basement, but although pleasant, it lacked natural sunlight. Food was plentiful and good for breakfast and dinner. The room was of appropriate size and had a plasma tv, and was well decorated. Internet connection was superb, and free. Lots of Westerners stayed at the hotel too. This was my 3rd trip to Beijing, and I will choose another hotel next time.

Mar 6 2006	Good but a few mis-steps.	Stayed there eight days in February. Overall experience was fine, with the exception of a few service hiccups. Rooms are more than adequate; the breakfast buffet is terrific, especially the Asian side; and the restaurant, while pricey, is quite good. Location is terrific. Generally, service is fine, but sometimes spotty at the concierge desk. Asked them to make reservations for Peking Opera one night, and they told me they would. Got to the opera, none had been made. Raised the issue when I returned, was told they would look into it and get back to me. No one did. When we reserved, we received a questionnaire asking our preference in newspaper, we never got one. Asked whether we would like comforter or blanket, we said blanket, got a comforter. Quite fine hotel, but doesn't quite live up to the promise of the Rolls Royce out front. Given the language barrier, it lhelps to be very specific.

Mar 1 2006	Excellent Hotel	My wife and I stayed 5 nights departing 2/28. Overall this is a wonderful hotel. The buffet breakfast is outstanding. Service was above average. Free internet service is provided in each room, both wifi and wired (connect speed sometimes is slow). Gym is very nice.The only negatives, which I do not consider serious were that the outside look of the hotel is nothing to write home about, and the room was a little small. Location is good, about a 15 minute walk to Tianamen Square. Many restuarants in the area. Pedestrian shopping street is a 5 minute walk.

Feb 26 2006	Great ammenities!	Just came back from an eventful trip to Beijing with my family. I must say that our vacation was enhanced by choosing the Peninsula. After exciting and often tiring days sightseeing with children, it was refreshing to return to 5 star accomadations. However, I don't believe that the service was always 5 star. I don't feel that it was for lack of trying but more of not knowing. Beijing is still growing as an international city and I believe that the more exposure they have in the service industry, the more they will be acccustomed to the needs of the travellers..

Feb 25 2006	What a great experience!	I stayed at this property Feb. 8 - 14, 2006. Couldn't have been more pleased with the room, great shower in the bathroom, service, location and overall experience. The breakfast buffet served at Jing each morning was something to look forward too. I also enjoyed the best massage I've ever had at the Peninsula spa. First rate! Also check out the small, very good restaurant right across the street.

Jan 16 2006 	This is a quite overrated Hotel	Having stayed at this hotel twice on my trip, i think this is a overated hotel. Probably one of the best in Beijing, not in this world.The room is simply Too Small. At an average of 31 metres, if you have more than one big suitcase, it is hard to put down two at the sametime. There is lots of details in the room ( like big TV etc). The Bath room is Tiny, compared to the Peninsula Bangkok.Since their Tub&Shower is in one place, my shower cracked the first time i used. I switched to China World Hotel on my third night stay there. Room at China World Hotel is much more spacious, a bit more expensive of than that of Peninsula BJ, but worth it.The location of the hotel is excellent, restauant at ground Fl is good.

Jan 11 2006	5 star luxury	For luxurious attention to detail this has to be one of the best hotels I have ever stayed in!The rooms are elegant - oh so comfy bed, Egyptian cotton sheets and lots of pillows. A beautiful limestone bathroom that even had an adjustable plasma screen tv you could watch in the bath.Room service was excellent as was the food in the restaurants. Staff very helpful. Taxis sometimes a little difficult to get hold of as they don't have a taxi rank on site.Word of advice - some American and European visitors might find the many porters ringing on the door - offering ice, chocolates for your pillow etc - a little annoying just remember to light up your 'do not disturb'on the control panel if you want to be left alone.

Jan 2 2006	Wonderful Experience	This hotel was amazing - we stayed for 3 nights. The room was elegant yet comfortable. We paid a little more for the club level, but it was well worth it. Also, the hotel's spa was small, but we each had relaxing and affordable massages, which were nice after a long day of travel. Don't hesitate to stay here.

Dec 5 2005	A Comfortable Elegant Home Base While Staying in Beijing	My husband and I stayed at the Peninsula for 4 wonderful nights. We read so many wonderful reviews about the hotel and couldn't wait to experience the hotel for ourselves; we were not disappointed at all!We loved the comfortable bed and oversized towels. It was such a treat to return back from a long day of sightseeing and have our bed turned down with ornemental pillows carefully slipped in their cases, slippers on each side of the bed, bottled water at the bedside, and soft music playing. The breakfasts at Jing restaurant were wonderful complete with a vast array of fruit, pastries, breakfast meats and they will cook your eggs to order.Service was outstanding and this hotel definately deserves the 5 star rating.

Dec 3 2005	One of the top hotels in China	I stayed at the Peninsula Palace earlier this year and it was great although service could be better.Location: I always thought it is adjacent to Wangfujing from the maps, but in reality you have to walk few minutes to reach it, and yet another few minutes to reach Oriental Plaza. From this point, the Tiananmen Square and Forbidden City is another 5-10 minutes walk. If location is paramount, the Grand Hyatt is better as it sits atop Oriental Plaza. The China World is also conveniently located atop World Trade Center with great shopping Center (and ice skating rink).Lobby: Opulent and grand with dramatic atrium and white carrara grand staircase leading to either business centre & ballroom upstairs or the impressive collection of luxury boutiques and restaurants downstair.Service: Check in was swift, where I was escorted right up to my room, which is quite personal considering the size of the hotel (500 plus rooms). Concierge, however, was a bit of let down. I requested a simple task to re-confirm my airline ticket to Jakarta but they could not find the phone number / location of the airlines office in Beijing. They made several attempts to call the Hong Kong and Shanghai office, but I was told to wait. I even asked them to check the net for the address, but still no result The next day, I followed it up but still yet to be confirmed. At the end, I went up to the business Center and rent it's 15 minutes internet for 30RMB and found the phone details myself, give it to the concierge and straight away got it confirmed.You can rent DVD for free from a list of options. Mine took more than half an hour and a few calls to get it delivered.Rooms: There are no impressive views from the hotel. The Deluxe rooms (31 sq.m) are located on the sides (possibly could have distant view to the forbidden City from top floors). The Grand Deluxe rooms (34sq.m) face either the main entrance or the indoor pool on the podium with distant view towards Chang An avenue. Opt for Grand Deluxe rooms as they have larger bathroom with separate shower and bath and TV.Rooms are not as large (e.g Grand Hyatt Shanghai 40m2, Island Shangri-La HK 44m2, Ritz Carlton Singapore 50m2), but they are superbly furnished. Teak wood with rugs, mood lighting, comfortable sofas, plasma tv, personal fax machine, DVD players with some music CDs selection and great control panel by the bed.Bath: Grand Deluxe bathrooms are large, with small TV by the vanity and control panels by the tub. Bath amenities are not great, nor are they designer brand as with other top hotels. Restaurant: My rates include a buffet breakfast at Jing, which is located at the basement. Although it has no view / street frontage, it is still feel very cozy. The design is great especially the private rooms. The breakfast food is allright, but not superb: quantity is not great but has good quality.Facilities: Check out the 50 luxury boutiques (from LV, Gucci, Prada, Tiffany) which can be handy for shopaholics. The pool was closed at that time, but should be nice with glass skylight when open.Rates: When booking the hotel, should check out directly to the hotel's website as sometimes they have good bargain with rates down to USD 160, incl. bfast (rack rates are USD 340).

Nov 29 2005 	Great Stay at the Peninsula Palace	I just returned from a six night stay at the Peninsula Palace Hotel in Beijing. The hotel is nicely located, a few blocks away from the Wangfujing shopping district and a 20-30 minute walk from the Forbidden City and Tiananmen Square.The hotel has excellent facilities including a pool / fitness center, a shopping mall in the basement, good room service, and a spectacular restaurant  Huang Ting. I stayed at this hotel for business and had a grand deluxe room on the club level. The club level rooms are about $50/night more expensive than the regular rooms but they include free breakfast, afternoon tea / desserts, and evening snacks in the 13th floor club lounge. Drinks, Internet access, and clothes pressing are also free and, in my opinion, round out a worthwhile upgrade from the regular rooms. My biggest gripe with the club level is the lack of authentic Chinese food and snacks  almost everything provided was too Americanized.The best feature of the hotel is probably the rooms with all their extravagant gadgets and amenities including a flat panel TV in both the bedroom and the bathroom, and a control panel next to the bed that controls everything from the TV and radio to the temperature and mood lighting. The control panel seems to have a motion detector built in so the lights on the display turn on as you move your hand closerneat.If you dont speak Chinese it is useful to have a card to hand to taxi drivers that identifies your destination in Chinese characters. The concierge at the Peninsula Palace has some of these with popular destinations printed on them. Interestingly, the cards dont include the airport as a popular destination (the one place almost every visitor would need to go eventually!). My theory is that this is because the hotel is more than happy to arrange one of their comfortable but pricey limos for this service. Even if you do take a taxi, the doorman knows to call the more expensive 2.00 yuan/km rides over the standard 1.60 yuan/km onesvery clever. A few tips from my stay:1. Single men should be prepared to be approached about 50 times between the hotel and the Forbidden city by young women pretending to study English or just looking for fun;2. Do visit the weekend market to buy some quality arts and crafts at low prices;3. Dont wear shorts regardless of the weather  it is bad form  I can count on one hand the number of people I saw wearing shorts in Beijing over a one week period (all misinformed tourists); and4. Dont buy things from government-run Friendship stores or jade/jewelry factories included in itineraries to the Great Wall unless you enjoy paying 10X too much for merchandise. Even the trips organized by the Peninsula Palace include these annoying stops.Overall, I would certainly consider staying here again, but next time I might try the Grand Hyatt just to sample some of Beijings other hotels. The Grand Hyatt looks very nice and is located at Oriental Plaza, slightly closer to the Forbidden City and the subway.

Nov 25 2005	Above Average Hotel	Stayed for three nights in June 2005. Slightly overrated. While the rooms were clean and modern (plasma t.v., purified water in the bathroom), they are very small. Hotel guests are mostly white Americans, not that that is a bad thing but being in the hotel, you would never know you were in China (except for the staff). Great location, excellent service, clean/modern facilities, good Western-style restuarant for buffet breakfast, luxury shopping within the hotel.

Nov 24 2005	Fantastic hotel	I stayed in this hotel with my family for a few nights in September 2005. We were upgraded so we got fabulous rooms that were really spacious with plasma screens including one in the bathroom. I liked the way every night when I came back from a tough days sightseeing there was classical music playing in the room. The food was fantastic there, especially the breakfasts. Ate in both restaurants there and can recommend the Hua Ting, try the duck pancakes, but beware you get a lot of duck!The locatin was perfect, you could just stroll down to wangfujing for shopping. I would definitely stay there again if i was in Beijing.

Nov 12 2005 	Surrounding Areas less than to be desired	What do you do if your husband gets a major chronic back pain, which leaves him bedridden for 2 full days, whereupon he asks me, his wife, for one of those "Tibetan Pads" to stick on his back?Of course I go get it, after I had a nice lunch on the LL1 floor of Jing Restaurant with one of my best friends...So I ask Marie, the concierge, where she can get me Chinese medicine pads and she gladly pointed out a Pharmacy, which is about a brisk 14 minute walk to get to. After checking on the cell phone with my ailing husband, I knew I got the right pads in a shop filled with all kinds of boxes of medicines. Tonight I pack to check out of the Peninsula Palace in Beijing tomorrow morning. I note how amazing this hotel's service has been: the room service, the house keeping, the waiting staff at the restaurants. (Hua Ting, on LL 2 is very good Chinese fare. Order cold appetizer/salads. )Then I go through my receipts to find the pharmacy overcharged me by 13 more pads! Unbelievable! I hear Wang Fu Jing is a cheating neighborhood for tourists, but this is just too much! WATCH YOURSELF IN THIS AREA! (If you won't buy anything, then don't worry so much. This is a great hotel. The lobby's upscale mall has decent window dressing compared to others in Beijing.)

Nov 11 2005 	Believe the hype about this one!	My weeklong stay at the Peninsula Palace was fantastic from start to finish. They sent a questionnaire beforehand asking about bed, refreshment, and newspaper preferences, so when I got there my room had the requested amenities. The location is fantastic, close to shopping, two subway stops, the Forbidden City and Tianamen Square. The room was superb, luxury linens and towels, a bedside control for literally everything in the room, including a 42 inch flat screen TV. It was very quiet, a nice respite from the hectic traffic (and unbelievably polluted air) outside.Compared to many four star hotels in the city, this property is pretty expensive, but less than the Hyatt and the St. Regis. I opted for the club floor for an extra $30 a night. I guess it was worth it, because the onsite restaurants were quite pricey (but it was nice that room service cost the same price for a selection of the same dishes). The selection at breakfast, afternoon tea, and evening cocktails was rather limited. But there is a nice lounge with internet access and free beverages all day.I would definitely stay at this property again!

Oct 28 2005	Excellent	First class hotel 10 minutes walk from Forbidden City and five minutes from main pedestrian shopping street. Decent size room, with 2 plasma TV's (one in bathroom). No views worth mentioning. Fine service overall. Concierge will book Great Wall and other tours (not cheap). Our Great Wall-Ming Tombs guide spoke excellent English. Terrific breakfast buffet included in room price. Would highly recommend this hotel. Fairly priced.

Oct 28 2005	Worth the money!	A treat at a true 5 star hotel. We noticed the difference the moment upon arrival. A representative escorted us to the front desk including an offer to carry my business case. Then the front desk staff who checked us in personally took us to our room and explain how every ammentiity works in the room. The hotel also make every effort to accomodate our special requests. Room is very contemporary with marble tiles and hard wood floor and a large plasma TV including state of the art electronic control on all electrical appliances. Central air is efficient and quiet which is uncommon. One feature that one would appreciate in China is that it come with filtered water at the sink rather than just bottled water. Hotel location is great. The Jing Restaurant was great for breakfast. All staff are friendly and helpful leaving you with a personal touch . We used the business center for internet bottled water was provided while we surf. Upon checked out when a private car was waiting to take us to the airport, the hotel manager would personal come over and inform us personally and ensure even our our departure exxperience was a pleasant one.

Oct 22 2005 	Great location beautiful rooms excellent service	As a travel agent, I stay in many hotels each year. The Peninsula Palace is one of the best. The group I brought to China loved this hotel. The location is excellent for shopping and sightseeing, right in the center of the city. Be careful of luxury hotels (or any hotels) in Beijing. The city is huge and the traffic awful. You can stay at a great hotel in the city that is half an hour or more from the Forbidden City. Our room was beautifully furnished and quite soothing. Room amenities were amongst the best I have ever encountered. Make sure you get the turn-down service - it makes going to bed a special experience. A hotel such as this in New York or London would cost twice the price. Go to China and take advantage of fabulous hotels at remarkable rates.

Oct 19 2005	Great spot for 5 star luxury in Beijing	This was our 2nd stay at Peninsula Palace and it remains a favorite. We were in a Duplex Suite on the 14th floor. It was FABULOUS. Huge, 2 story suite. Ground floor had half bath, living & dining area, flat screen TV. Hit a button and the drapes open/close on the 2 story windows. Stairs to 2nd floor loft style space. Huge desk & work area, large bed, another flat screen and loads of storage space for clothes, etc. Bathroom was big with 2 sink areas and yet another TV in the wall at the end of the tub.Service was excellent. Shoes shined & returned almost instantly. Room service was quick & good. Duplex Suites are on Club Room Floor and the Club Lounge (on 13th Floor) was lovely. Easy service in checking in/out and huge breakfast, afternoon snack & evening cocktail spreads. Very comfortable. Only complaint would be that they only had 1 computer to use for internet, etc. and it was busy a lot (However, there was a business center on 2nd floor). Location is excelllent. Walk out the door, down the street and you are on a huge pedestrian street filled with shopping. In the evenings, there's a great food stall market...go to see the crickets/silkworms, etc. on a stick! Easy 20 minute walk to Tiananmen Square/Forbidden City. If you're looking for luxury...we thought Peninsula Palace was far better for the price than St. Regis.

Sep 27 2005	REALLY GREAT PLACE TO STAY	We stayed on the exec floor (13th) and got a reasonable rate through a club. You will pay more for this hotel, but the location and staff are both excellent. No need to take hotel taxis, especially to airport, as Beijing Taxis are cheap and effificient. Many many things within walking distance of hotel. Do check out the breakfast, afternoon tea and happy hour on the executive floor. We never ordered room service given these options for free;)

Sep 4 2005 	Nice hotel but not GRAND	I stayed there 5 nights and enjoyed my stay. But it was not what I would call an exciting 4 or 5 star hotel. There were several problems and the hotel staff only corrected the problem and did nothing extra. When I arrived, I was escorted to my room which was great because the door lock was broken. I was told they would fix the door and told it was take half a day and come back. I was offered nothing in return. I then told them to give me another room but everything was sold out. I was told a better room was available the next day, so I booked it and I paid the higher price. The second room had a much larger and nicer bathroom, but not to the level of other top 5 star hotels. The first room looked very basic. The lobby is nothing to get excited about. The entrance to the hotel is nothing to get excited about. But, in the lobby and 2 floors below the lobby is a mini shopping mall with every major luxury brand store. And these stores are not the usual hotel mini version, the are full size. That was surprising since they seemed to be empty everytime I walked by. Over all I enjoyed my stay. Both rooms were on opposites sides of the building, so I got to see the main road view and the pool side view. Neither are what I would call impressive. So don't go there for the views! The hotel staff were nice. When I came back late on my second day to move to my new room, a staff attendant noticed me enter the lobby and immediately told me my new room was ready. That was impressive. I guess she waited there all day? The location is great. I was not so impressed to stay there automatically on my next trip. I booked this hotel because I saw it was rated #1 by internet users. But I would say it's a nice hotel, but not GRAND. I walked to the Hyatt and that hotel looked impressive from the "outside". So I will probably try there next time.

Aug 26 2005	Hotel of Supreme Harmony	My husband and I stayed for 8 nights in this superb hotel. We had booked a Duplex suite but were upgraded to the Beijing suite when we arrived. I had been in contact with the hotel before our arrival to ensure our booking had been received and to tell them about our anniversary which was to take place whilst we were there. This appeared to be a good move as the lady I had communicated with acted as a personal concierge whilst we were there and we received a complimentary bottle of champagne on our anniversary, (this may also have been because we were staying in a suite of course).The hotel is very grand. It is spotlessly clean and has an impressive lobby area complete with sweeping staircase and a fine array of designer shops. The receptionists are helpful and courteous and we did not have to wait long for attention even at busy times.Our suite was beautiful. It consisted of lounge, dining area, office area, bedroom, bathroom with his and hers sinks, and a separate toilet. There was a plasma screen in the lounge and in the bedroom, and the bath had a LCD TV at the foot which was fully controllable via easily-reachable buttons at the side of the bath. There were far more channels available than I had been told to expect, e.g. BBC World News and three film channels. The air conditioning was excellent and the complimentary toiletries were of good quality. The minibar, was well stocked; a beer was about 35 RMB (which is about 2.20) which is not the end of the world. I particularly liked the 'mood lighting' available, very romantic! The hotel has its own restaurants, which is handy as China is quite a difficult place if you don't speak Chinese and don't particularly wish to sample the locals' food. The Jinn restaurant is where breakfast is served and we found it to be of superb quality. You could literally have anything you wanted - cereals, full English, omelettes, pancakes, fresh fruit or Chinese. At busy times, 8am to 9am, it gets very busy and you may have to wait for a table but it is not too painful and everyone is very courteous. In the evening the Jinn restaurant serves 'Fusion' food which, to my mind, means Western-style Chinese food that isn't very Chinese at all. Try the duck pancakes, oh try them please!!! My mouth still waters at the very thought. The other restaurant we visited in the hotel was the Hong Qiou which serves more traditional Chinese food; you can even have Shark's fin if you want to pay the ridiculous price! We went for the safe option and had sweet and sour pork, duck, beef with mushrooms, noodles etc. This too was fabulous and honestly not very expensive. A word of advice...if you order tea don't order water as well. We made this mistake without realising that they will keep topping up the tea indefinitely and so we ended up with tea, water and beer!If you have had a tiring day the other option is room service. We had this a couple of times and were never dissappointed. If you are missing your burger and don't like McDonalds after watching 'Supersize me' (I still can't get the non-decaying fries out of my mind), then room service does the most delicious burger ever...mmmmmm burger. Just make sure that you remember that all prices are subject to a 15% Service charge which we still can't work out, particularly when they then leave a space on the bill for 'tip'.As part of our package we had access to the club lounge. We found this area invaluable. You can have breakfast here but it is far more limited than the Jinn restaurant. In the afternoon they serve the most delicious scones with cream and jam and other fancy little sweet things, so vital for the ladies after a long morning haggling in the market! In the evening they have a small buffet of meats, cheese and tacos. You can also help yourself to alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks. We found the club really great before and after having a meal in the hotel. We had drinks in the Lobby bar on our anniversary and gulped at the bill when we could have had complimentary drinks in the club!The location of this hotel is ideal. It is right by the Wangfujing shopping precinct and either a walk or a very short and cheap (70p) taxi ride to the Forbidden City and Tianeman Square. Taxis are extremely easy to get right outside the hotel lobby and are cheap and reliable. The hotel organised a Hutong tour for us and a hotel taxi to the Summer Palace and Great Wall. Although far more expensive than if you organise it yourself I suspect it was well worth the extra money, our taxi driver actually showed us around the Summer Palace like our own personal guide.All in all an amazing experience that I would love everyone to share.
Aug 21 2005	The best hotel i have ever stayed	Best facilities, best services, best value. We will definitely stay here again.

Aug 2 2005	Wow absolutely amazing am so impressed!	I can tell you I was so looking forward to staying here after looking at their website and the comments left here. Can I assure everyone out there that this hotel is brilliant! They really think of everything, and once you step out of the taxi pulling up at the hotel you really dont need to worry about anything at all.I was in a Deluxe Room registered with the CLub Lounge so I had access to free food and drinks all day and they have a great afternoon tea bit between 3-5pm where they serve the most delicious chocolate cakes and pastries, everything complimentary, inc internet usage. I would well recommend it!Breakfast was very good too with a really wide selection, inc smoked salmon, parma ham, a full english and American breakfast and asian dimsum too with teriyaki fish, mmmmmmmm.Now one of the best bits was how modern the room was itself. Its a reasonable size with 2 double beds, and a massive plasma screen in it and also a smaller one in the bathroom where you can watch dvds/tv in the bath, which I did, how pampered was I! Plus they have all these controls by the bed so you really dont have to move! They have around 100 dvds you can choose from but th annoying thing is alot of them are hired out and you dont have to return them until you check out, so ended up watching some knockoff dvds I bought in a subway which also worked fine.If you want your room made up you press a button 'make up my room' and then a maid comes from housekeeping in literally a couple of minutes. My only gripe is that when it came to getting a taxi back to the airport they called a rather expensive black one and not a normal taxi, and this one didnt have a meter in it and charged us 120 yuan whereas to get to beijing from the airport only cost me 70 yuan in a metered taxi! so next time before you hop in, check its got a meter!Otherwise I cannot recommed this hotel enough. Its location is fab too, its about 5 min walk from Wangfujing st, just go out of the hotel and turn left and walk 5 mins and Wangfujing is on your left.
Jul 18 2005	The best I've ever stayed	staff, service, facilities... A wonderful place to stay and rest. Do not hesitate, it's worth the money...

Jul 12 2005	Wonderful respite at a decent price	Stayed here for a night of luxury after a month of backpacking - for a promotional rate of only $145! The DVD selection and the plasma TVs were a nice touch, and the staff is very helpful. I do have to agree with the previous comment about the taxi hotel service - you're better off catching one on the street on your own.

Jul 11 2005	The Beiing Peninsula er...Palace	I've got to concur with a previous review that while the Beijing Pen is pretty good-it does pale in comparison with its namesake in Hongkong or Manila. I was so ready to be wowed at first glance; I suppose my expectations were over-reaching upon arrival. For starters, it is not an easy walk to the Forbidden City--it's a good 25 minute romp. Nevertheless, the front desk was most accomodating, giving me a choice for another room when I requested for one with a better view. Some literature might lead you to believe you'll get one with a view of the Forbidden City--most doubtful as the hotel is around the bend.The plasma tv's were excellent and the dvd/cd players were thoughtfully bedecked with 2 cd's, one jazz the other chinese classical--I thought these were excellent ideas. And as for the bathroom with flat screen tv's...now you'll really stay in the tub for hours.As for the food--Huang Ting was good and quite beautiful. Jing for breakfast was alright...a bit jammed with people, all lined up along the egg station...nothing gets the caucasian crowd rousing and bitchin like making them wait for their eggs. Jing for dinner, with all due respect to the Conde Nast list--was a bit of a disappointment.Still, everything else in this hotel is mighty spiffy--from the front desk, to the lovely shopping halls, to the gym, swimming pools and steam rooms...the Beijing Peninsula is excellent...I'm just not sure if it's really deserves to be called a PALACE. PS: Make sure you check out the Wangfujin map they unwittingly hide in the desk--outlining all the little pocket pleasures you'll find in the neighborhood.

Jun 27 2005	Excellent Hotel Stay	Excellent hotel. Service was great. From the time of check-in we were whisked to the club level where we were served drinks & snacks while they processed our check-in. Anything we asked was done promptly. They try to meet your every need. The entire staff was extremely friendly. I was impressed how ell they spoke English. Workout facilities & pool were very nice.I thought the Huang Ting restaurant was outstanding. Many peolple rave about Jing, but our meal there was only so-so. The only negative thing was the hotel taxi service. It was considerably more expensive than the regulat taxi. Having said that its a small negative.My family is still talking about our hotel stay there. We think this is the PLACE TO STAY in Beijing.
Jun 15 2005	Great Hotel!	The staff at this Hotel are very nice and always willing to help. The buffet is to die for. It was so nice to come back to after a busy day of site seeing!

Jun 2 2005	This Ain't the JW Shanghai...	This is a solid hotel. Whether it is up there with the cream of the crop in the 5 star family of luxury/premier hotels is debatable - think the flagship Peninsula HK, the Ritz Carlton, JW Marriott and Grand Hyatt in Shanghai, the Oriental & Regent in Bangkok. I am not thinking the Peninsula Palace Beijing.My comments are minor 1s but when the barometer of comparision is set by such outstanding properties as those noted above, they are noticeable. Staff to guest ratio was good but nothing out of the ordinary, always had to wait for cabs, the concierges seemed overwhelmed at times, construction around the building started at 7am each morning so one had no choice but to get up (& could also not take an afternoon nap), the drainage in the bathroom was like my old college dorm room. Again, nothing severe but chinks in the armour of any 5 star contender. Huang Ting / Chinese rest. was excellent - both quality & value wise. Conversation-interrupting Peking duck. I have to stop thinking about the duck now... I also went to the famous Peking duck rest. on the busy street behind T. Sq / Mao's maus. that every guidebook &/or mag/newspaper articles mentions (I think opened since the late 1800s). It's ok. But so is a Toyota Camry & if i can pay the same price I'd rather have the Lexus. You pay the same amount but the quality of the duck & the service cannot be compared without tempting ridicule from little children. Zing, the other rest., is where breakfast is served - as the other reviews on this site note, excellent. Lots of choice - from western food to dim sum. Gets busy in the rush hour morning traffic though (seems to be a lot of tour groups at this hotel). However, the rest. is also highly rated for it's dinners (Conde Nast ranked i think) - my sis tried it out for dinner but she has yet to give me the thumbs up or down. Conclusion: if you can get a decent rate, go for it. Otherwise, you may want to check out the Hyatt (connected to the Oriental Plaza - great food court here!)

May 20 2005	Stay Here	What can I say but fabulous, this hotel have got it right. The moment we walked into foyer we were treated wonderfully. We travelled all over China, and we also have travelled most of the world, but I have to say that this hotel has the best breakfast buffet I have ever seen. The rooms were wonderful and exceptionally clean.I cannot praise this hotel or Beijing enough. I am returning in September and would never stay anywere else.Stay here with the greatest of confidence.

May 4 2005 	Truly magnificent. A real 5 stars for a very reasonable price	Extremely well situated, walking distance from the Forbidden City and Tienanmen Place. Luxurious hotel, with a mix of traditional with modern. Splendid decor. Room and bathrrom of a real 5 stars. Restaurant facilities outstanding from breakfast to supper whether in the Jing or the Huang Ting where we ate a most delicious Peking duck ( we even had it on 2 different occasions!) Impeccable service, from registration in your own bedroom, to first class conciergerie service . Most polite staff doing their best to accomodate you in all aspect of the stay. Were driven from and to airport in a mercedes limo. Help of 2 Peninsula's bellboy at the airport ( they stay there all day to accomodate incoming and outgoing client) to make sure we got our connecting flight to Shanghai. Took us all the way to the gate. Luxurious berroom and bathroom with daily changes of towels and faucet for purified water. TV while taking a bath or on a huge plasma screen in the bedroom. Great hallway with a little bar where you can enjoy 3-5 musicians playing either classical or soft music. 3 floors of the world most prestigious boutiques in the hotel,although you must expect to pay more than at home. Go shopping in the markets of Beijing where bargaining is a tradition and a must. Fitness of the first quality. In all a most enjoyable stay at a truly 5 stars hotel. And the price beats most other 5 stars in Beijing.

May 2 2005	An oasis in Beijing	As others have noted, the Peniunsula Palace is an oasis within the noise, chaos, and dirt of Beijing. Renovated just a few years ago, rooms are decorated in an Asian-Western fusion style with silk bed accessories and hi-tech plasma TVs. Bathrooms are compact but practical with soaking tubs and granite and marble features--plus the amusing bathroom TV. Staff at the hotel are outstanding and consistently helpful and attentive. We especially enjoyed the beatiful fitness and spa facilities, including a wonderful indoor pool area and the thoughtul items tucked into each locker: robe, plush towel, flip-flops, and even a drawdstring plastic bag with which to transport wet bathing suits. The breakfast buffet, included with most room rates, is heavenly--a perfect mix of dim sum, Japanese, and the usual western standards. Of all the hotels I have stayed in in China, the Peninsula has by far the best breakfast. Service at breakfast can be slow, however; tea and coffee cups routinely run dry, and the pancake and waffle maker seems to take a lot of breaks. For other meals, the restaurant Jing is relatively unremarkable except for its great decor, which you can enjoy at breafast anyway. Our dinner there was solid, but hardly inspired, from a culinary perspective and frustrating from a service perspective (we couldn't find a member of the wait staff who spoke enough English to communicate my allergy to milk products, and I ended up with a dinner soaked in butter tnat had to be sent back). Huang Ting, the hotel's other major restaurant, is much better with an antique Chinese decor, highly attentive service, and great Chinese food. Overall, this is a great hotel. Other perks include the easy walking distance to Beijing's major shopping district, the nightly Snack Market (only for the brave!), and major sights in the city, including the Forbidden City.

May 1 2005	Excellent hotel in Beijing	Although many new hotels continue to pop up in this bustling city of 15 million people, the Peninsula Palace is still a great place to stay. The location of this hotel is exceptional with a pedestrian mall only a block away. The hotel had well appointed rooms although ours wasn't huge. It offered two twin beds (actually doubles). The bathroom was beautiful and even had a TV allowing you to view while in the shower or bathtub. They also had a separate water faucet in the bathroom for drinking which made it nice to brush your teeth. I did so daily with no ill affects. They managed to maintain coolness in the rooms all night long, which is important to sleep soundly. Breakfast was included and was at Jing restaurant. Exceptional. The best array of international breakfast cuisine we found on our trip to China. They also have internet access that runs about 45 Yuan for 15 minutes or $8.50 US. The staff was very pleasant and most spoke English. They were helpful and like any you might find at a first rate hotel in NY. All in all a great place to stay.

Apr 25 2005	Peninusla is a Palace!	Just returned from Beijing. 4/16/05-4/23/05. Stayed at the Peninsula Palace. What a fantastic hotel. From the minute we stepped out of our car till the moment we left we were treated wonderfully. It did take quite a bit of getting used to, as in the states we are not accustomed to such service and attentiveness. We are just normal folks who expect to do most things for ourselves...In fact, my 25 year old daughter commented on her trip back from the restroom by the lobby bar, that the attendent did everything short of going to the bathroom for her!!!! This hotel is number one is service and it is also beautiful. We had a standard adjoining room that was well appointed and decorated with a great view of the main street. The breakfast included in our room rate was delicious and the restaurant was beautiful looking as well. I have absolutly nothing negative to say about this hotel. The last time I went to a hotel that was as wonderful all around, was at the Ritz Maison Orleans in New Orleans, LA, USA. Peninsula Palace, You are tops, and you will see me again next trip!!!~Elle

Mar 20 2005 	Fantastic	This hotel was wonderful from start to finish.When we checked in, although we had a Chinese speaker with us they insisted on speaking English. The service from all of the staff throughout was prompt and impeccable. One of our party had a birthday while we were there and they sent a birthday cake to her room.The rooms were newly decorated and immaculate with everything you could want down to a TV in the bathroom. The buffet breakfast in Jing was the best I had in China and had a really good choice of western and Chinese food. This was included in our rate of 135USD a night (+ tax). This is a beautiful restaurant unfortunately we did not have the chance to eat there on an evening. We did order room service one night, which was not bad and reasonably priced for a five star hotel. The hotel had lots of other facilities that we did not have time to take advantage of, although we did have time to wander around all of the designer shops in the lobby. The only problem was that there was work ongoing during the day, which was quite noisy while trying to nap off jetlag, but this stopped by six o clock each night.Based on my experience there I would recommend this hotel to anyone.

Mar 16 2005	Best Place in Town	Everything about the Peninsula Palace was spectacular. However, the service definitely stands out alone as the best reason to come to this hotel. The staff, at all levels, were terrific and incredibly helpful. The hotel underwent a recent renovation and the facilities are outstanding. Our standard king bed room was spacious for a city hotel, well appointed with nice modern furnishings and contained the large plasma TV that other reviewers raved about.We got a club level room that came with club amenities and it was well worth it. The club lounge served a delicious breakfast each day, had snacks and afternoon tea and then appetizers with evening cocktails. We took advantage of all the offerings of the club lounge during our stay.We also ate at both hotel restaurants and we found them to be quite reasonable (in US dollars standards) and very good. Huang Ting, the chinese restaurant in the hotel, was very good and highly recommended. One note of caution, we went out to the Quanjude Peking Duck restaurant one night which was raved about in several tour books as THE place to go for Peking Duck. We were rather disappointed at our expensive meal there and not at all impressed. Perhaps we just had bad luck...The location of the hotel is also excellent as it is within walking distance of the Forbidden City & Tiananmen Square as well as some very good malls for shopping and eating.I would highly recommend the Peninsula for anyone traveling to Beijing!

Feb 25 2005	Service luxury and location - it has all three!	Nov 04 - this was my second trip to Beijing, taking American friends on side-trips out of Hong Kong. Its amazing what a great hotel experience will do to change your opinion of a city. On my last visit (Apr 04), we stayed at the New Otani which was a disappointment and detracted from our overall Beijing experience.We arranged hotel transfer from the airport which was seamless. Upon arrival at the Peninsula we were met in the motor lobby by hotel staff and immediately escorted to the club lounge, an experience which makes you feel special and your business valued. We were booked at the club level and received superb check-in from the club staff. There was a mistake in one of the room reservations needing twin beds (which I had re-confirmed by phone 2 days prior), which wasn't available, and so they upgraded my companions to a suite. Excellent recovery.The rooms were lovely and housekeeping staff was very, very good. Bathrooms in double room were a little tight (nothing beats Singapore Ritz-Carlton on bathrooms), but nonetheless very nice. Room light and TV controls are state of the art as well as the flat screen TV on the wall which leaves you plenty counter space on top of the bureau! The room has a great chaise lounge which is a nice alternative to always relaxing on the bed.Business center performed a quick task without as much as a hesitation.Concierge staff was amazingly patient and accommodating with very good recommendations. Dim sum at the hotel restaurant was delicious. Breakfast, tea and cocktail hour at the club level were well worth it.My husband and I are very discerning hotel guests and have stayed at many of the top hotels in Asia. This hotel exceeded our expectations.

Jan 31 2005	By far the best	We stayed at the Peninsula Palace in mid-January at the end of our visit to China, and it proved to be the perfect ending to our trip.
